Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Probing SARS-CoV-2 evolution and vulnerabilities through its mutation and fitness landscape
Award.AbstractNarration: A major challenge in the fight against viruses is their enormous amount of genetic diversity resulting from large population sizes combined with high mutation rates. However, the frequency at which such variants appear and the consequences of specific mutations on viral fitness are largely unknown for SARS-CoV-2. Researchers supported by this award will measure the mutation rate and fitness landscape of three SARS-CoV- 2 isolates from around the world. The work could be essential for accurately modeling the future evolution of SARS-CoV-2 and may help identify the virusâ€™ vulnerabilities at the molecular level. Results from these studies will also be leveraged by undergraduate students and researchers for training in advanced genomic analyses. The findings and data from these studies will be published in peer-reviewed journals, presented at scientific meetings and in public STEM engagement activities, and shared on-line through blog posts and the popular press.<br/><br/>Research supported by this award will measure variant frequencies in viral populations following several rounds of serial passaging in Vero E6 cells. Genome-wide measurements of all possible variants frequencies will be accomplished using the circle-sequencing to measure mutation rates and fitness landscape virus. Changes in variant frequencies over the course of serial passages will be used to derive the relative fitness of each variant. Knowing the mutation rate (and spectrum) of the virus is paramount to modeling its future evolution, including the rate at which resistant variants are expected to arise. By measuring the fitness of thousands of mutations across the genome, the researchers hope to identify residues and protein domains that are critical to the virus replication cycle and narrow the range of protein domains and residues to target with therapeutics. Among these sites, those for which no other mutation can rescue the viral fitness will be of particular interest. This RAPID award to University of Southern California is made by the Division of Biological Infrastructure using funds from the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Viruses are incredibly small and yet they can cause great harm to humans. They accomplish this feat by producing billions of copies of themselves, spreading within and across individuals at great speed. Each time a viral particle replicates, it must create a copy of its genome. The genome can be seen as the blueprint, or book of recipes, for making more viral particles and is made of about 30,000 nucleotides (imagine a recipe written with 30,000 letters but only 4 characters: A, C, G or U allowed for each letter). Random errors (for example, replacing a C with a U) happening during this process are called mutations. The change in the genome sequence caused by these mutations can impact the ability of the virus to infect other cells and replicate. Some mutations will prevent the virus from performing its normal life cycle (we say that these mutations are deleterious for the virus) while others might make the virus more performant at infecting and replicating (advantageous mutations for the virus).

In this project, we employed state of the art genomics methods to precisely measure how frequently mutations occur in SARS-CoV-2. We found that mutations occurred at a rate of about 3 base-substitutions for every one million nucleotides replicated. In other words, after one viral particle replicates to make 10 copies of itself, we expect to find one mutation among these 10 copies. While this number can sound small (many writers would love to make only 3 typos per one million characters typed…) it results in about 100 million new mutations in each infected individual (assuming each infected individual eventually carries about 1 billion viral particles). Some of these mutations can become the foundation of new variants.

We note that the mutation rate measured here is in-line with our expectations based on other viruses. Indeed, there is a strong negative correlation between mutation rate and genome size among viruses, and the mutation rate reported here fits perfectly within this correlation, as expected with a virus from a natural origin.

A significant achievement of our project was to identify variation in the mutation rate across different regions of the SARS-CoV-2 genome. We also quantified the impact of these mutations on the fitness of the virus. Mutations that make the virus better at replicating/infecting are classified as advantageous, mutations that reduce the efficiency of replication/infection are called deleterious (the most extreme case being lethal mutations, defined as those that completely prevent the virus from continuing its life cycle) and mutations that do not affect the fitness of the virus are called neutral. We found that many mutations previously thought to be neutral (because they do not change the amino acid encoded at this position) are actually deleterious. Our results indicate that many of these mutations disturb the secondary structure (i.e. the three dimensional shape) of the RNA molecule that encodes the genome of SARS-CoV-2. This results highlights the potential of therapeutic targets that would target the stability of the SARS-CoV-2 secondary structure.
